reviews.review_msg: Jacqueline was great! Very nice and approachable. Going to her office hours was invaluable as her feedback brought my writing up from a low B to a solid A. Not a lot of work either! Material is quite dry though.

Professor Turner is a great teacher who offers lots of good advise to aspiring writers. Creative writing workshops attract some slackers, but she handles them well by enforcing a strict schedule. Don't take her class if you expect to breeze through. Lots of reading a writing will be expected.

If you make the effort to connect with her instead of sitting through her classes like a sack of meat, you'll do well. She's a genuinely sweet person and clearly wants you to succeed - any deficits in her lecturing ability come from shyness and lack of confidence, not any shortcomings in knowledge.

Shes a great prof, she really wants you to do well. Assignments and readings are not bad, you just need to take her advice and use it. I ended with a B+, learned a lot, class was little long, but other than that I enjoyed her class.

Prof Turner is very helpful, approachable and kind. Her classes get some getting used to but tie in the concepts learned very well. Assignments and final were very fair. Use all her edits on your papers and put in the effort to ask for help because she genuinely wants you to do well. She helped me get an A in a class I dreaded at the start of sem!

Prof Turner is amazingly helpful, approachable and kind. As long as you put in the effort to ask for help she's more than willing to give you it. Her teaching gets some getting used to, but ties everything from the textbook to her lectures well. Her assignments and final were very fair. Follow any and all advice she gives, definite grade booster.

What a great prof! Finally, a prof that actually cares about her students. She is very approachable and always willing to help make your essay better. She is a tough marker, but if you listen to her advice and follow it in your essay, you should be okay. Extremely personable and always happy :)

Just BRUTALLLLL. Holy lord, I took this class my first semester of university and it kind of put a giant shade of grey on the already cloudy sfu. I didn't learn much, my TA was sweet and what I did learn; I learned from her. JT does her entire lecture on an overhead through her computer, but she is completely computer illiterate. Poor. Dont do it.

Took this course with her last sem.  One of THE most boringgg classes ever, and as said by others, she does plainly reads off the MSWord notes.  You can just skip and not miss a thing basically.  Definitely a newbie at teaching.  I took the course only because the other courses were full.  Think carefully before you take this course.
Not a great prof by any means.
Do no take this course! Lectures are boring and useless.
Easiest class ever.. couple essays and final. I could have skipped every class and miss nothing!!
Boring classes, class is full of wannabe poets. Do not take course. Id rather take women studies or first nation studies. I regret taking this course.

Reads directly off her MS Word notes, and stutters a lot while doing so. Takes awhile to post her notes up on WebCT. Her course focuses on contemporary poetry--I personally didn't like it so much because I couldn't understand, but to each his own, I guess. You do NOT have to know ALL the poems for the final like the other poster said, just some.

worst prof ever. boring lectures and useless notes. i think she is a good poet, but she just doesnt know how to teach. she says one word ummmmmmmmmmm next word ummmmmmmmm ... but fairy easy class. good TAs for sure.

Lectures are boring, do not take this course if you need a writing course, only take this course if you know you are good at writing papers. Expects you to remember all the poems read throughout the semester for the final. AVOID TAKING THIS COURSE UNLESS YOU HAVE TO!!

try to avoid taking poetry with her. Although she may be a good poet, she certainly CANNOT teach. She is very amateur and her lectures consists of her reading (and stuttering) directly off the slides. I still cannot understand how she became a professor at SFU
